headline: Reserve Bank Slashes Interest Rate to 3% Amid Widespread Teacher Strikes and Heated Parliamentary Debates
summary: Parliament was dominated by major economic news as the Reserve Bank cut the Official Cash Rate, offering relief to mortgage holders. However, the announcement was set against a backdrop of intense political clashes over ongoing teacher strikes, the costly final settlement for the cancelled KiwiRail ferry project, and rising unemployment for Pasifika communities.

topicSummaries.topic: Reserve Bank Slashes OCR to 3%, Offering Mortgage Relief
topicSummaries.content: Minister of Finance Hon Nicola Willis announced the Reserve Bank has cut the Official Cash Rate (OCR) by 25 basis points to 3%, its lowest level in three years. She celebrated the news, stating it would provide significant cost-of-living relief, with a family holding a $500,000 floating mortgage saving around $330 a fortnight. The Reserve Bank also signalled two more potential cuts this year. The announcement was challenged by Labour's Hon Barbara Edmonds, who questioned the government's economic recovery narrative by pointing to a 56.6% increase in KiwiSaver hardship withdrawals, totalling over $470 million, and a 37% rise in company liquidations.

topicSummaries.topic: PM Clashes With Greens Over Teacher Strikes and 1% Pay Offer
topicSummaries.content: Prime Minister Rt Hon Christopher Luxon faced sharp questioning from Green Co-leader Hon Marama Davidson regarding nationwide teacher strikes. Davidson highlighted that teachers were striking over a 1% pay offer while inflation sits at 2.7%, and noted that at least 65,000 essential workers had taken industrial action this year alone. Luxon urged unions to negotiate rather than strike, stating his government was working to get wage growth ahead of inflation, a contrast he drew with the previous administration. In a separate exchange, Minister of Education Hon Erica Stanford defended the government's position, arguing that investments in teacher registration fees and learning support demonstrated that teachers are valued.

topicSummaries.topic: KiwiRail Finalises $144 Million Settlement for Cancelled Ferry Project
topicSummaries.content: Minister for Rail Rt Hon Winston Peters announced that KiwiRail has made a final settlement payment of $144 million to Hyundai following the cancellation of the Project iReX inter-island ferry project. Peters heavily criticised the previous government's handling of the project, stating it had already cost $671 million with little to show for it and was projected to escalate to $4 billion. He described the original project's plans, which included new terminal buildings, as "nonsense" and "Taj Mahals in Picton," asserting the government's new "no-nonsense" solution would save taxpayers billions.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Under Fire as Pasifika Unemployment Doubles
topicSummaries.content: Minister for Social Development and Employment Hon Louise Upston was questioned by Labour's Hon Carmel Sepuloni over a significant rise in Pasifika unemployment. Sepuloni stated that 6,100 more Pasifika people are now unemployed compared to last year and that the rate has doubled since the government took office. Upston acknowledged Pasifika are disproportionately affected and defended the government's focus on economic growth and programmes like community coaching. She also defended cutting $22 million from the Tupu Aotearoa programme, stating the funds were moved to the Ministry of Social Development (MSD) to leverage stronger, existing programmes.

topicSummaries.topic: Medsafe Cuts Medicine Approval Times by Over 100 Days
topicSummaries.content: Associate Minister of Health Hon David Seymour reported that Medsafe has significantly reduced the time it takes to approve new medicines, cutting over 100 working days from assessment times in the last two years. He praised the work of Medsafe's team, led by Chris James, for aligning New Zealand with jurisdictions like Australia and Canada. Seymour also promoted the government's upcoming "Rule of Two" legislation, which would fast-track medicines approved by two other comparable countries for use in New Zealand within 30 days.

conclusion: The day was defined by the economic relief from a major interest rate cut, set against a backdrop of intense political conflict over public sector pay, rising unemployment for specific communities, and the costly fallout from a cancelled infrastructure project.
